newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan forex policy not aimed at exports - Sakakibara.
newsitem.headline: Japan forex policy not aimed at exports - Sakakibara.

text.p: Japan has never deliberately tried to weaken the yen to boost exports, Eisuke Sakakibara, a key Finance Ministry official, said on Saturday.
"We have never implemented a policy to weaken our currency to promote exports," Sakakibara, director-general of the ministry's International Finance Bureau, told a business seminar.

Sakakibara, dubbed "Mr Yen" by world traders because of his influence on exchange rates, was in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka to attend the annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) which formally opens on Sunday.

He said it had taken financial markets time to digest an agreement on foreign exchange rates reached by the Group of Seven (G7) industrialised nations in April in which they called for markets to concentrate on economic fundamentals.
"It's like cold Japanese sake. It takes time to hit you," he said.
Earlier, Sakakibara told reporters he did not consider a nearly six yen rise by the Japanese currency against the dollar over the past week to be excessive.
"No. It is not overly excessive," he said.
